ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about Israeli music from the establishment of Israel to the present day. I also engaged in class discussions and wrote writing responses daily to improve my verbal and writing skills.

I raised my active and passive language skills, benefitting heavily from the strong classroom discussion in each class. I broadened vocabulary and fixed persistent errors. I worked toward having better matching between verbs and required prepositions.
I developed the ability to write and speak Hebrew in an academic setting. My writing and speaking skills improved and I also learned a lot about Israeli culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Sometimes, the number of assignments due per class was very overwhelming. However, the rigor of the class certainly helped improve my Hebrew.

I loved the ongoing GoogleDoc that helped me track my writing progress and errors, allowing me to be in constant dialogue with Dina about any grammar or linguistic questions I may have. I also liked that anytime a student either didn't know a word, or used a high-level word unfamiliar to others, Dina put it onto a running vocabulary list that we were responsible for translating part of and choosing which words we wanted on an exam. A great way to grow vocabulary. No weaknesses. Fewer graded speaking assignments in this class than others, but because class was so highly discussion based I wouldn't have asked for more graded speaking assignments; my speaking and listening comprehension really grew in the course.
The content of the course is very interesting, and the discussions around it were enjoyable. No complaints.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course if you are looking for an interesting and engaging Hebrew class and you are curious about Israeli music.
Definitely, the classes had a good mix of pre-planned and student-driven topics. The focus is on improving Hebrew across reading, writing, and speaking skill areas.
Definitely. If you want to improve take this course or any other course with Dina. But if you don't want to improve, maybe don't take the course.

I would recommend this course to another student if they were interested in learning about Israeli culture or if they had a solid grasp of Hebrew and wanted to practice writing and speaking (the homework would be challenging for anyone who does not have a strong background in Hebrew).
